Title:
Morphological and molecular identification of two new
Ganoderma species on Casuarina from China
Keywords:
Ganodermataceae, medicinal mushroom, morphology, taxonomy,
wood-rotting fungi
Abstract:
Ganoderma is a cosmopolitan white rot fungal genus, and
famous for its medicinal properties. In the present study, two new
species Ganoderma angustisporum and G. casuarinicola were collected on
the southeast coast of China and identified on the basis of
morphological characters and phylogenetic analyses inferred from the
internal transcribed spacer (ITS), the translation elongation factor 1-α
gene (EF1-α) and the second subunit of RNA polymerase II (RPB2). These
two new species are both found on living trees of Casuarina and they are
compared with related taxa from other regions of the world. Ganoderma
angustisporum is characterized by its sessile basidiomata,
almond-shaped, slightly truncate and narrow basidiospores (911.3 × 45.2
µm). Ganoderma casuarinicola is characterized by its strongly laccate
reddish brown pileal surface, luminous yellow to yellowish brown cutis
and ellipsoid basidiospores (910.2 × 56 µm). Phylogeny confirmed that G.
angustisporum and G. casuarinicola are clearly distinct species within
Ganoderma.
